etymologies: late 17th century. Apparently from a compound or phrase in a southern variety of Chinese, perhaps compare (Wu: Ningpo) da ts'ing steelyard from da large, great (Mandarin dà) + ts'ing scales (Mandarin chèng); compare Malay dacin

definitions: A balance used in China and East Asia, consisting of a beam with arms of unequal length, and having a scale suspended from the shorter arm and a counterpoise which can slide along the longer arm (which is notched or graduated).

notes.text: The dotchin is similar in form and use to a steelyard.
